title: How to Invest $1.5 Million in Retirement for Continuous Income
subtitle: A strategic plan for retirees to ensure financial stability without running out of money.
content:
How to Invest $1.5 Million in Retirement for Continuous Income

I'm Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager. Now I make financial content for free, so you don't have to pay for it.

1. Invest in an S&P 500 Fund

I would put 90% of my portfolio, or $1.35 million, in an S&P 500 fund like Fidelity's FXAIX. This gives me exposure to some of the most profitable companies in the U.S.

2. Hold in a Money Market Fund

The remaining 10%, or $150,000, would be kept in a money market fund like Fidelity's SPAXX. This provides liquidity and stability.

3. Monthly Withdrawals

On the second day of each month, I'd sell 0.4% of the FXAIX, which would equate to about $64,800 a year pre-tax.

4. Annual Income from Money Market Fund

With a 3.5% annual yield from SPAXX, I'd add an additional $5,250 per year in income.

5. Projected Social Security Benefits

I'd project about $30,000 a year from Social Security benefits, bringing my grand total to $100,000 a year pre-tax.

6. Tax Efficiency

If I keep my gross income under $98,900 (married filing jointly, 2026), I pay 0% tax on the FXAIX gains.

7. Growth Projection

If the market returns about 7% in real terms on average per year and I'm only drawing down 5%, then my portfolio is projected to continue to grow even as I'm spending it.

8. Sequence of Returns Protection

In case of a bad sequence of returns—like a market crash in my first couple of years—I have $150,000 in a money market fund to tap into. I can spend during downturns and then replenish when the market recovers.
